message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the availability and finite nature of certain resources. While it is true that all of the options listed are limited in some way, coal is the resource that we will eventually exhaust. Coal is a non-renewable fossil fuel, meaning that it takes millions of years to form and cannot be replenished within a human lifetime. Water (option A) is a renewable resource, as it goes through the natural water cycle and can be recycled. Air (option C) is composed of different gases and is constantly replenished through natural processes such as photosynthesis. Time (option D) is a concept rather than a physical resource, and it is not something that can be exhausted in the same way as tangible resources.

This question requires some basic knowledge about finite resources. While all the options listed are important resources, only coal is a nonrenewable resource that can be completely depleted. Water can be recycled and replenished through the water cycle. Air is a mixture of gases that is constantly being circulated and replenished. Time, although finite for each individual, is not a resource that can be exhausted in the same way as the other options.

This question requires some basic knowledge about finite resources. While options (A), (C), and (D) are all essential for life, they are not finite resources that can be "exhausted." Water, air, and time are constantly replenished or exist indefinitely. However, coal is a non-renewable resource that is being consumed faster than it can be formed, leading to its eventual exhaustion. Option (B) is the correct answer.

This question requires some basic knowledge about natural resources and their availability. Coal is a finite resource that is formed over millions of years from the remains of plants and trees. It takes a very long time for coal to be replenished, so eventually, we will exhaust our supply. Option (A) is incorrect because water is a renewable resource that goes through the water cycle and can be replenished. Option (C) is incorrect because air is a mixture of gases and cannot be exhausted. Option (D) is incorrect because time is not a resource that can be exhausted.

This question requires some basic knowledge about finite resources. While all of the options are important resources, coal is a non-renewable resource that is being used at a high rate and will eventually be depleted. Option (A) is incorrect because while there may be regional shortages of water, the Earth as a whole has a constant supply of water through the water cycle. Option (C) is incorrect because while air pollution is a concern, the Earth's atmosphere is made up of a mixture of gases that will not be completely exhausted. Option (D) is incorrect because time is not a finite resource, but rather a concept used to measure the progression of events.

This question requires basic knowledge about natural resources and their sustainability. Coal is a finite resource that is being widely used for energy production. As it is non-renewable, we will eventually exhaust our supply of coal. Option (A) is incorrect because water is a renewable resource that can be replenished through the water cycle. Option (C) is incorrect because air is a naturally occurring and renewable resource. Option (D) is incorrect because time is a concept and cannot be exhausted in the same way as physical resources.

This question requires some knowledge about the availability and usage of different resources. While it is true that our supply of water, air, and time are limited in some ways, they are not exhaustible in the same sense as coal. Coal is a nonrenewable resource, which means that once it is used up, it cannot be replenished. On the other hand, water and air go through natural cycles of replenishment through processes such as the water cycle and photosynthesis. Time is not a resource that can be exhausted as it is a constant and measures the progression of events.

This question requires some basic knowledge about finite resources. Coal is a non-renewable resource, meaning that it cannot be replenished at the same rate it is being consumed. Eventually, we will run out of coal. Options (A) and (C) are incorrect because water and air are renewable resources. Option (D) is incorrect because time is not a resource that can be consumed or exhausted in the same way as physical materials.

This question requires an understanding of the concept of finite resources. While options (A), (C), and (D) may eventually have limitations or be influenced by human activities, they are not considered exhaustible in the same sense as option (B) - coal. Coal is a non-renewable resource and its supply can be completely depleted over time. Water is a renewable resource through the hydrological cycle, air is a mixture of gases that is continuously replenished, and time, while limited for individuals, is a concept rather than a physical resource that can be depleted.

This question requires an understanding of finite resources and the concept of exhaustion. While options (A) water, (C) air, and (D) time are all essential resources, they are not exhaustible in the same way that option (B) coal is. Coal is a fossil fuel, which means it is a non-renewable resource that takes millions of years to form. Once we extract and burn all the available coal deposits, we will no longer have a supply of coal. On the other hand, water and air are renewable resources that can be naturally replenished, and although time is finite, it is not a resource that can be exhausted in the same sense as physical resources like coal.

This question requires basic knowledge about limited resources. While all of the options are limited resources, coal is the one that we will eventually exhaust. Water (option A) is a renewable resource through the water cycle. Air (option C) is a mixture of gases that make up the Earth's atmosphere and is continually recycled through natural processes. Time (option D) is not a physical resource but a concept. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer as coal is a non-renewable resource that will eventually run out.

This question requires some general knowledge about finite resources. The supply of water (option A) is renewable through the water cycle, so it is not something we will completely exhaust. Option C, air, is abundant and constantly replenished through natural processes, so it is also not something we will exhaust. Option D, time, is a concept and not a physical resource, so it cannot be exhausted. Option B, coal, is a non-renewable resource that is extracted from the earth's crust. It takes millions of years to form and once we have used up all the accessible coal deposits, we will no longer have a supply of coal. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) coal.

This question requires some basic knowledge about finite resources. While all the options listed are important resources, coal is a non-renewable resource that is being used up faster than it can be replenished. Water is a renewable resource that can be treated and recycled, and while air pollution is a concern, the availability of air itself is not at risk. Time is not a resource that can be exhausted, as it is a concept and not a physical substance. Therefore, the correct answer is option (B), coal.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the finite nature of resources. Coal is a non-renewable resource, meaning that once it is exhausted, it cannot be replaced. Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they are not resources that can be exhausted in the same way. Water is a renewable resource that can be replenished through the water cycle. Air is composed of gases and is not a limited resource. Time is a concept and not a resource that can be exhausted.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the availability of resources. Option (B) is correct because coal is a finite resource and will eventually be completely used up. Option (A) is incorrect because water is a renewable resource, although it may become scarce in certain regions. Option (C) is incorrect because air is a naturally occurring and renewable resource. Option (D) is incorrect because time is a concept and cannot be exhausted in the same way as physical resources.

This question requires knowledge about finite resources. While all of the options are important resources that we must preserve, coal is a non-renewable resource that will eventually be exhausted. Option (A) is also a concern but there are ways to recycle and conserve water. Option (C) is necessary for survival but is not a finite resource. Option (D) is a concept rather than a physical resource.

This question requires some general knowledge about non-renewable resources. Coal is a non-renewable resource that is being used faster than it can be replaced, meaning we will eventually exhaust our supply. Water and air are both renewable resources, and while they can become polluted or scarce, they are not finite resources that we will completely run out of. Option (D) is incorrect because time is a concept, not a resource.

This question requires some basic knowledge about natural resources and their limitations. Coal is a non-renewable resource, meaning there is a finite amount of it that can eventually be exhausted. The other options are renewable resources or cannot be fully exhausted (at least not in the foreseeable future) - water can be recycled and purified, air can be replenished through natural processes, and time is an abstract concept that cannot be "used up."

This question requires knowledge about non-renewable resources. Coal is a non-renewable resource, meaning that once we use it up, it cannot be replenished. Water and air are renewable resources that can be naturally replenished. Time is not a resource, but rather a measurement of duration. Option (B) is the only answer that pertains to a non-renewable resource that can be exhausted over time.

This question requires knowledge about nonrenewable resources and the current state of their availability. Coal is a nonrenewable resource and therefore there is a finite amount available on Earth. Options (A) and (C) are not accurate because although they may be affected by human behavior, they are renewable resources and can be replenished. Option (D) is not a resource, but a concept.
